awd_titl_txt: Interface Engineering of Fiber Reinforced Calcium-based Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
The use of discontinuous and randomly oriented nano/microfibers (steel, carbon, polymer) as reinforcements in calcium-based materials for civil and biomedical applications has received increasing attention due to their promising potential for superior structural and multifunctional composites. The interface between the fibers and the matrix plays a vital role in material performance and must be accurately characterized to effectively design materials. The goal of this research project is to understand reinforcement mechanisms in fiber reinforced calcium-based composites. Fundamental understanding of key features of fiber reinforcements will enable better material design and fabrication strategies. The broader impacts are twofold. Civil engineering applications: Advanced materials that extend the life of civil infrastructure, reduce maintenance costs, and enhance safety and sustainability will save billions of tax dollars a year and have many magnified indirect effects on society. Biomedical applications: Advanced biomimetic materials will provide more effective medical treatments. The educational component will introduce high school students to the intriguing science of the very small and will develop a graduate level course module on material durability.

The goal is to fundamentally understand the molecular structure and dynamics at the fiber-solid-liquid interfaces that control reinforcement mechanisms in fiber reinforced calcium-based materials with an emphasis on determining the nature of the interface and how it relates to interfacial mechanical behavior. The focus is on the molecular to nanoscale and the chemo-mechanical interactions at reinforcement matrix interfaces. Molecular dynamics modeling and experimental characterizations of the structure and dynamics of the interfaces will be integrated to (i) elucidate the interfacial interactions between fiber surfaces, calcium-bearing solid phases, and surrounding liquid phases, (ii) quantify and relate the effect of the chemical structure to the mechanical properties of reinforcement matrix interfaces, and (iii) formulate molecular dynamics-informed interface cohesive traction-separation relationships that connect the molecular scale to the micro-continuum scale at interfaces. The research will (i) provide a molecular to nanoscale picture necessary to achieve improved engineering properties, (ii) make advances in relating chemistry and mechanical properties at interfaces, and (iii) bridge the gap between nano-mechanics and micro-mechanics at interfaces.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The research investigated the interfacial molecular structure and dynamics at reinforcing structure-solid matrix phase-liquid phase interfaces that control the reinforcement mechanisms in fiber reinforced calcium-based materials with an emphasis on the major factors determining the properties of the interfaces and how they relate to the nanoscale mechanical behavior. The focus was on the molecular to nanoscale and the interface between the reinforcement and the matrix.

Motivation. Calcium-based materials are an important class of materials in the civil and biomedical fields. Major weaknesses common to both areas of application are quasi-brittle fracture properties and low tensile strength. The use of discontinuous and randomly oriented nano/microfibers (steel, carbon, and polymer) as reinforcements is a common strategy to improve the material strength and failure resistance. Lately, their use in civil engineering structural materials (calcium silicate cement composites) and biomedical materials for regenerative medicine (calcium phosphate cement composites) has received increasing attention due to the promising potential for the development of superior and multifunctional structural composites and bio-compatible nano-composites. Among the various phenomena that influence fiber reinforced calcium-based materials, interfacial interactions between the solid matrix phases, the reinforcement, and any surrounding liquid are the most important in controlling the overall mechanical response and damage mechanisms of the composites. Understanding the role of the solid-solid and solid-liquid interactions and the structure and behavior of these interfaces is critical to the global behavior and thus the ability to design calcium-based materials with superior mechanical performance and durability.

Intellectual Merit. The nanoengineering of the mechanical properties (tensile and shear) of crystalline calcium-silicate-hydrates (C-S-H) via a single-layer graphene sheet (GS) and the traction-separation relations for C-S-H/GS interface systems in normal and shear directions were investigated using molecular dynamics simulations. The major factors affecting the nature of the reinforcement-matrix interface were evaluated and included (i) the geometrical assembly of the GS within the C-S-H structure, (ii) the surface structure of C-S-H interfacing with the GS (water, calcium, and silicate surfaces), and (iii) surface functionalization of the GS with hydroxyl (-OH) groups (percent and arrangement of -OH groups in random and clustered line patterns). The anisotropic structure-topology-property relations of -OH functionalized graphene and the normal and shear traction-separation relations for graphene bilayers with and without nanoconfined water monolayer were also studied.

Results demonstrated the potential for tuning the mechanical properties and fracture pattern of graphene through controlled surface modification. Functionalization of the GS with -OH groups arranged in clustered line patterns led to strong elastic anisotropy of the GS. The line pattern functionalized graphene acted similar to a nanoscale mechanical spring with an increased stiffness in the direction parallel to the line patterns and an increased linear compressibility in the direction perpendicular to the line patterns. The results further indicated that graphene can be uniquely tailored using line pattern functionalization to combine in-plane stiffness, compressibility, and fracture toughness in specific directions.

MD simulations of the mechanical behavior of tobermorite/graphene nanocomposites provided new insights into the nano-engineering of calcium-silicate-hydrates. For example, the incorporation of GSs into tobermorite 9 A (crystalline structural analogue for C-S-H) as an intercalated or stacked arrangement was shown to contribute to a significant increase in its in-plane tensile strength, stiffness, and strain energy density, indicating the potential of the use of hierarchical architecture for enhancing the properties of calcium-based materials. The GS was found to significantly enhance the in-plane tensile (180%-360%) and shear (90%-225%) strengths, stiffness, and strain energy density while degrading the out-of-plane properties of tobermorite 14 A-based structures. The role of water at the reinforcing structure-matrix interface and the influence of the interface characteristics on the mechanical behavior of the composite upon loading were revealed. For example, there was more in-plane strengthening when graphene interfaced with water due to molecular friction (intermolecular forces) than with dry solid surfaces (calcium and silicate surfaces). Furthermore, the strength of the composite was shown to be influenced by the orientation of the GS (higher strength for zigzag direction than armchair direction) and the presence of hydroxyl functionalization on the GS.

MD simulations of the traction-separation of the interface between tobermorite and graphene with and without hydroxyl functionalization and the presence of water provided new insights into the interface failure mechanisms at the nanoscale and the role of water molecules on the strength of the interface in graphene reinforced calcium-based materials.

Broader Impact. The research has resulted in two (2) peer-reviewed manuscripts, two (2) conference proceeding papers, and several presentations at international conferences and professional meetings. The project has also resulted in a Ph.D. dissertation and provided research opportunity for one high school student. A graduate level course module on modeling of interfaces for the design of innovative civil infrastructure materials has been developed.


Last Modified: 11/29/2019
Modified by: Florence Sanchez
